contextId.information: Here the word "you" is singular and refers to Abraham. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
Paul is talking to the critics of his teaching as though he were only talking to one person. You may need to use the plural here. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
contextId.quote: You will say then to me

contextId.information: This refers to the nation of Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

The pronoun "you," and the phrase "a wild olive branch," refer to the Gentile people who have accepted salvation through Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: if you, a wild olive branch

contextId.information: Paul is addressing the believers here. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

All occurrences of "you" in 13:9 are singular, but the speaker was addressing a group of people as if they were one person. If this is not natural in your language, you may need to use plural forms here. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
singular. Because Paul is addressing the believers, you may have to translate this using plural. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
